card.desc:
Req: EVO220155
Budget: 114K
RFx: RFP
3D Scanning - reverse engineering 
Stakeholder: Kevin Brennan - Foreperson Everett Shop
writing SOW 2-3 wks with Ed Belanger. 
Selection Team:
12/3/2021 - sent introduction & planning email
1/28/2022 - Brennan SOW wk of 1/31
Is vendor's solution the only one that works with "SolidWorks" engineering program? NO.
Is vendor's solution the only one that is ISO certified including ISO reporting certified as required? Supposedly. This will need to be pass/fail.  
KB discussed needs with Creaform who was then invited in for demo. Creaform submitted a quote. 
I walked him through the correct bid process.
He didn't have a formal SOW at the time Creaform was engaged but knew this would go out to bid. 
Follow up 1/6 for SOW status.

data.text:
Deadline extended for bond and insurance, 2/9/2022

1/25/22; B. Kuhn "its not that we are not interested.  It seems now that we can get the bond we found that the $5M umbrella policy you want for insurance will cost me another $5K/yr as well. I am trying to shop that around. Between the two things the job is going to cost us more than we thought.  In the meantime we are servicing the machine on our dime. I can understand if you feel you need to rebid it, but honestly anyone else coming in is going to need our cooperation and assistance as well, since this is basically a proprietary design, few of which were built in the USA. "
PO denied, missing documents. Documents expected on 1/28/22.

The purpose of this Request for Information (RFI) is to gather information from qualified industry parties for the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority (MBTA) to use in the   development of technical specifications and other procurement documents for procurement of a new fleet of light rail vehicles for MBTA’s Green Line.  These vehicles are designated the Green Line Type 10 Light Rail Vehicles and are conceptually described in the document GL10-00008 Type 10 Concept Report.
Goals of Green Line Transformation are to:
•	Increase Green Line passenger capacity
•	Increase the service reliability and safety of the Green Line
•	Restore the entirety of the Green Line to a state of good repair
•	Increase accessibility of the Green Line.

cards.desc:
Description:  MBTA Work Car and Rough Order of Magnitude Estimate BACKGROUND: The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority (MBTA) is pursuing a project for and the procurement of the self-propelled Maintenance of Way (MOW) vehicles: (a) Overhead Catenary System (OCS) Wire Inspection Cars for the Blue and Green Lines and (b) Crane Cars for the Red, Orange, and Blue lines and (c) two Vacuum trailer cars. a) Two (2) OCS Wire Inspection Cars will be used primarily for inspection and light maintenance of the OCS wire and related equipment. They must be capable of performing wire inspections in either direction between revenue trains during off-peak hours, and provide the ability to record and transfer wire inspection results. Additionally the MBTA now desires a second trailer car with an OCS Wire spool and a bucket lift to support wire replacement b) Three (3) Crane Cars will be used primarily for track and signal maintenance, including lifting and transporting equipment such as rail, special track-work, signal equipment, and related. The ability to transport rail is mandatory and it is expected that a semi-permanently coupled flat car will be required to provide sufficient storage. NEW: Additionally the MBTA is considering the addition of a non-powered flat car pair for use with the crane car PURPOSE: This cost estimate is intended for capital planning purposes only to support Capital Investment planning. It is anticipated that this estimate will be updated, revised and modified based on the information and data obtained during the Request for Industry Information process that is currently underway. ROUGH ORDER OF MAGNITUDE COST ESTIMATE UPDATED: ESTIMATE NOTES: 1. This estimate is based on the conceptual functionality and performance requirements as they are currently understood. 2. This estimate assumes award in 2017. 3. This Estimate includes a seven year warranty period. 4. Vehicle Variance we reduced to 10% (previously 30%) 5. Procurement Contingency was reduced to 8% (previously 15%) 6. Vehicle quantity for the Crane and OCS car have doubled from 3 to 6 and 2 to 4 respectively. 7. Both Vacuum cars are unpowered. 8. Source Rev 3 Rom Worksheet Procurement Value Differences between the February 2017 and August 2017 Estimate

cards.desc: We are looking to develop a partnership with a Contractor able to provide professional spares supply and management services to enhance the utilization and value for money of the new Red and Orange Line cars. As it is done with the new blue line fleet, the MBTA will be transitioning to an RCM approach in support of the new Red and Orange Line vehicles. This will be implemented as the vehicles are accepted into service and as components come due for scheduled maintenance.  This will maximize component life while minimizing the risk of component failure.  This will also allow the MBTA to create predictable schedules for spares and labor based on the estimated service lives of components being targeted.  Implementing an RCM program on the vehicles focused on maintenance tasks at the correct frequency will lower the amount of in-service failures and improve reliability significantly.  End User: Jerry Polcari

cards.desc:
Description: The MBTA has an interest in participating in regional utility programs supporting the rollout of Electric Vehicle charging stations. The utility programs are Eversource’s “EV Make Ready Program” and National Grid’s “Leading by Example EV Program”. In an effort at addressing first and last mile problem as well as statewide goals, the MBTA is exploring opportunities that may work in parallel with current utility programs for EVSEs. 
The MBTA would like to provide amenities to help address the first & last mile while remaining focused in its mission of providing public transportation. The goal of this RFI is to learn about innovative business models that will allow the MBTA to lease parking spaces to vendors who own, operate, and maintain the charging assets that supply energy to daily customers parking their electric vehicles in MBTA parking lots.

cards.desc:
Requestor Name: Dominick Tribone
Sponsor Name: Dominick Tribone
Department: Marketing & Communications
Email: dtribone@mbta.com
Phone: 781-234-5568


Description: Marketing & Communications for Silver Line 3 to Chelsea Background: In the Spring of 2018 the MBTA expects to open Phase 1 of its Silver Line Gateway project, extending Bus Rapid Transit service between South Station and the Seaport to Chelsea, with a connection to the Blue Line at Airport station. This service will provide a direct link between many parts of Chelsea and the employment centers of the Airport, Seaport, and Financial district and is projected to shorten commute times for thousands of passengers. The service will share the Silver Line Transitway tunnel with the SL1-Logan Airport and SL2-Design Center, and will be branded as the SL3-Chelsea Scope of services: The MBTA is seeking qualified bidders to develop and implement a marketing and communications plan for this new service. This plan will accomplish several broad goals, including: Advertising the new service to existing and prospective customers Highlighting the benefits of Bus Rapid Transit service relative to existing bus service, including dedicated lanes and limited stops Promoting the ongoing work of Phase 2 that will be continuing and the improvements it will bring If selected, you will work with the MBTA develop a well-rounded marketing and communications strategy that achieves these goals, including but not limited to specifying target audiences, generating message concepts, testing messages, producing graphic collateral, proposing an effective mix of media, and evaluating the effectiveness of the campaign(s). You might consider working with local community organizations as part of the public outreach strategy. We expect to be able to leverage our own media assets to meet much of the marketing and communication needs for this project. However, we are open to using paid media, including social media promoted content if you believe it is an effective marketing tactic. In such a case, you will purchase the media on behalf of the MBTA and should include that cost in your bid. Deliverables: Marketing and communications plan: how will we make customers and other potential riders aware of the service and its benefits? Marketing and communications materials: graphics, messages, and all other collateral to implement the plan Evaluation plan: how will we measure the effectiveness of the tactics included in the marketing and communications plan? Final report: implementing the evaluation plan and reporting on the effectiveness of the marketing and communications plan to the MBTA, including suggestions for improving future marketing campaigns Your firm’s technical submission to this RFR must include: 1.1 Description of team and methodology. Who would be on your project team? How would it be structured? What would be your project approach? We don’t expect that one firm will necessarily have all of the skills required for this project, and we encourage smaller firms to partner together. (Though for legal purposes, we will need you to designate one firm as the prime contractor and all others as subcontractors.) 1.2 Relevant examples of your work. Help us understand how you’ve approached projects similar to this one. How did you do the market research? How did you decide on tactics? 1.3 Inspiration. Please provide an example of: 1.3.1 A marketing campaign that got people thinking about a utilitarian product in a new light. 1.3.2 An innovative marketing tactic used to advertise a government service 1.3.3. 1.4 Project approach. Describe how you would approach the four deliverables outlined above. Provide us with an expected timeline for each phase using a Gantt chart or a similar tool. Please specify any support you would need from the MBTA to accomplish this work. 1.5 References. Provide three current customer references, including the following information for each client: company name; contact name, title, email and phone; length of engagement with client; a brief description of history with this client. 1.6 Financial statements. Provide a copy of your firm’s audited financial statements, including a detailed balance sheet and profit and loss statement for up to three years, or alternatively submit Dun & Bradstreet reports. Your firm’s financial submission should include a fixed price cost for the three project components listed above, as well as hourly rates for any ongoing support. 12. Evaluation Criteria Contractors must submit responses that meet all the submission requirements of the RFR. Only responsive proposals that meet the submission requirements will be evaluated, scored and ranked by the evaluation team according to the evaluation criteria. Additional information may be requested for evaluation purposes. Technical proposals will be evaluated using the following criteria: 1. Organization profile. Does the project team have the requisite level of experience and skills to effectively accomplish the goal of the project? Will they be adequately supported and resourced? What have other references said? 2. Past projects and inspiration. Past submitted work is both relevant and indicative of success on the project. Inspirational examples resonate with the vision of the MBTA in developing a more compelling product and customer experience. 3. Proposed approach and timeline. Approach is creative and thoughtful, and timeline is ambitious (though realistic). 
Estimated Cost: 75000
Funding Source: Capital
Spec Approver: dtribone@icloud.com
cards.name: RFR - Marketing & Communications Services for the MBTA

cards.desc: The MBTA is currently in procurement to replace the current fare collections system (CharlieCard and CharlieTicket ) to provide for an integrated, reliable and convenient fare payment and collection system (AFC 2.0) to enable transportation customers to pay fares by tapping contactless bank cards, mobile phones and fare cards across the MBTA network. This new account-based System will support implementation of a robust set of fare policy options for the MBTA, improve operational conditions, increase the security of transactions, and improve revenue control for the MBTA. The procurement will end with the selection of a vendor to deliver the AFC 2.0 system, known as the Systems Integrator.

cards.desc: The RDS program allows Plan Sponsors to go back and “reopen” past reconciled plan years to see if they captured all eligible members and eligible prescription drugs that qualify for Retiree Drug Subsidy. An RDS Reopening allows a Plan Sponsor to go back to previously reconciled RDS (Retiree Drug Subsidy) applications and request more subsidies.  The CMS (Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services) allows a Plan Sponsor to request a Plan Reopening for up to 4 years after a plan year has been reconciled to determine if they are eligible for additional subsidy. PO awarded on 01-26-18 to RDS.
cards.name: RFR 131-17: RDS (Retiree Drug Subsidy) Reopening Service

cards.desc:
The MBTA exploring options to provide service between the hours of 1am and 5am. During these hours, the MBTA closes the heavy and light rail service in order to perform vital maintenance. In addition, the demand for transit service is significantly reduced compared to our existing service hours. However, there are still transportation needs, especially for low-income workers.

The goal of this RFI is to learn about the feasibility of a cost-efficient solution that will provide service given the demand levels and different origin and destination patterns in this time period. The MBTA is considering a pilot of a possible solution for up to 11 months to test its success against specific performance metrics.
cards.name: RFI 83-17: OVERNIGHT BUS SERVICE

12/31 Tech Scoring Complete, but still await Frank's associated observations
1/11 Teleconf with Tech Team--RFCs for pricing & unit status'required of 
        Magnetech .
Bid pricing by 2 top scoring tech bidders did not include 2 x Main Overhaul AR10-CA5 Floats which was necessary for bidding as presented in the SOW. Due to their high technical scores, Bidder disqualification at this time was not reasonable. Main Overhaul AR10-D14 Floats were also requested in the posted RFP due to the uncertainty of which LOCO's were to be 1st in line for required generator upgrade. Due to the gap in tech scoring between the 2 top tech scorers and rest of the bidders, a request was made to the 2 top scorers to answer if the "no bid" submission by both bidders for Main Overhaul AR10-CA5 floats was accurate. Sherwood responded with a corrected bid due to the recent ability to bid on Main Overhaul AR10-CA5 Float. Magnetech responded to our clarification request with "no bid" - with response "At the current time, Magnetech does not have a CA 5 in our core pool. We could not supply the AR10-CA5."  It is unspoken but widely known that the Bidders have option to acquiring the unit and offer for resale to MBTA, should they choose. Nonetheless, a second "no bid" was issued by Magnetech. It was decided that Sherwood, in combination of their technical score and ability to provide the product would be considered the leading finalist. Steve Adkins will prepare agenda to confirm with Sherwood via teleconf their total understanding of the the specs, SOW, and acceptable lead times to complete the project based on the their on their recent ability to bid on, and provide the AR-D14 Main Overhaul Float.

Description:  MBTA Work Car and Rough Order of Magnitude Estimate BACKGROUND: The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority (MBTA) is pursuing a project for and the procurement of the self-propelled Maintenance of Way (MOW) vehicles: (a) Overhead Catenary System (OCS) Wire Inspection Cars for the Blue and Green Lines and (b) Crane Cars for the Red, Orange, and Blue lines and (c) two Vacuum trailer cars. a) Two (2) OCS Wire Inspection Cars will be used primarily for inspection and light maintenance of the OCS wire and related equipment. They must be capable of performing wire inspections in either direction between revenue trains during off-peak hours, and provide the ability to record and transfer wire inspection results. Additionally the MBTA now desires a second trailer car with an OCS Wire spool and a bucket lift to support wire replacement b) Three (3) Crane Cars will be used primarily for track and signal maintenance, including lifting and transporting equipment such as rail, special track-work, signal equipment, and related. The ability to transport rail is mandatory and it is expected that a semi-permanently coupled flat car will be required to provide sufficient storage. NEW: Additionally the MBTA is considering the addition of a non-powered flat car pair for use with the crane car PURPOSE: This cost estimate is intended for capital planning purposes only to support Capital Investment planning. It is anticipated that this estimate will be updated, revised and modified based on the information and data obtained during the Request for Industry Information process that is currently underway. ROUGH ORDER OF MAGNITUDE COST ESTIMATE UPDATED: ESTIMATE NOTES: 1. This estimate is based on the conceptual functionality and performance requirements as they are currently understood. 2. This estimate assumes award in 2017. 3. This Estimate includes a seven year warranty period. 4. Vehicle Variance we reduced to 10% (previously 30%) 5. Procurement Contingency was reduced to 8% (previously 15%) 6. Vehicle quantity for the Crane and OCS car have doubled from 3 to 6 and 2 to 4 respectively. 7. Both Vacuum cars are unpowered. 8. Source Rev 3 Rom Worksheet Procurement Value Differences between the February 2017 and August 2017 Estimate


Updated Bid Deadline 11/24/20. 


2/4 Posted Mike's 3 Amendments to the spec requirements and proposal suggestions.

Procurement: Fuel Management Information System - Buses
RFP: 88C-19
Spec: EE&QA-893
Requestor: Mike Walsh
Requisition: BUS042920A
Funding Source: MBTAC
Estimated Cost: $7.5 Mil
Committee Members: Mike Walsh, Jim Silva, Derek Hart, Kevin Petit, Ed Venini &  David Metraux - advisory  
COMMBUYS Bid Number:

The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority (herein the MBTA) provides fixed route bus and Para-transit van service to the City of Boston and the Greater Boston Area and is looking to purchase a Fuel Management System (FMS) for its fleet of revenue buses, Para-Transit and non-revenue vehicles. This system must be capable of managing, securely controlling and reporting the disposition in real time of all commodities used by the MBTA to include at a minimum engine oils, antifreeze, diesel exhaust fluid (DEF) as well as compressed natural gas (CNG), gasoline and diesel fuel.

10/24  1030a  Next Tech Team Mtg.
                       John Mehaylo making additional spec. revisions:
                       Michelin references, tire performance specific to
                       allowable damage tolerances, financial responsibilities for 
                       replacement re types of, and reason of, damage. 

10/31 11am    Next Tech Team meeting--continuation of additional spec.       revisions & references, tire performance specific to allowable damage tolerances, financial responsibilities for replacement re types of, and reason of, damage, and tech eval criteria. 

John M. finished tech eval criteria. Wtg Tech Requirements for Tire Samples  

11/26 Met with Jim Silva--John M. expects to have final Tire Test Spec over the next few days.     
12/14 John W & John M - completing Tire Testing spec & Deliverables
Per John M-- Michelin already performing deliverables as current vendor. The deliverables list is for a potential new vendor who would require "run out" transition from Michelin to ?  
12/21 Req'd Final Spec update from John M. on 12/20.
12/28 Per John M - trying to have final tire spec with John W. deliverables 
          on 12/31. Discussed with Ray - we're stuck. 
1/4 Met with Ray & Jim Silva--assemble package as currently constituted to post but 1st final review with Ray who is to schedule mtg with me.
1/4 & 1/7 reviewed Latest Mehaylo & Warhola specs - I posed question re tire replacement inclusive of proposed pricing as stated in latest spec. I requested an estimated/avg number of tires based on on current contract for which we ( I am told) have been provided at no cost. Requested verifiable information from Warhola. We cannot make this request without providing an estimate of replaced tires to prospective bidders - How can they calculate their bid?   
1/22 Per Warhola em-- working on preparing the tire damage table reports.
We will need to build a model based on the information to be provided by Warhola-hx of tire sizes and avg # miles damaged unable to complete service. 
1/23 One last push for spec finalization to Silva/Mehaylo
1/28 Final RFP  pre-posting Tech Meeting - Charlestown
2/8 Global Tire Damage Totals (2018) provided by current vendor.      
2/15 Warhola Spreadsheet Analysis Covered Tires & Costs                          2/15-2/20 Mehaylo Final Spec Requirements  
2/25 Publish RFP.   Timeline approved by Jim Silva.

6/19-7/19--Start of 194 New Hybrid Buses being delivered, and arriving 4/week - through 2020.  Spec'd by Bob Dacy to be built with Michelin Tires. 

2/11 Touching base -Jim Silva to find out Mehaylo & Warhola progress & get back to me. 
2/25 Called Jim Silva--Haven't recvd Warhola's updated damaged tire qty spreadsheet. Haven't recvd Mehaylo's final revised spec as promised. 
Silva is looking into it.
2/28 Rcvd Warhola's Tire Damage totals with cost savings.
Still waiting Mehaylo's final Spec. No word back from Silva. 

3/1-- 1429 tires/year replaced by incumbent for which MBTA is not financially responsible, bundled under "curb damage" category codes. This is the number to be included in the RFP to assist bidders to calculate their proposed pricing.  
3/4 - Called Mehaylo office and cell- got vm -lmsg re final status
3/21 Warhola completed run out spec, forwarded to Mehaylo for completion of remaining specs.
Bridge PO issued until spec finalized 
6 month bridge contract approved.
4/9 Per John Warhola--reviewed Mehaylo final spec, and still requires revisions. JW spending next 3 days to complete it - 4/10 
4/19 Silva told Ray should be completed by tomorrow.

cards.desc: We are looking for scheduling services providers with HASTUS experience to come in to audit and assess the way we currently use the HASTUS software and then come up with their recommendations on how we can modernize the way we plan our work. They will be implementing functionality to best practivce and new modules will be included. The modules of HASTUS look at different things such as if we have enough operators and vehicles. It also tracks all our buses geographically and provides our GPS, messages and announcements.  There will be two phases: 1.) Evaluate (assesment of the current utilization by the MBTA and recommend business process changes) and 2.) Configure (creation of Schedules following HASTUS best practices and subsequent user training). End User: Tim Colligan.

cards.desc:
Request for Information ("RFI") regarding New Green Line Type 10 Vehicles.

The purpose of this Request for Information (RFI) is to gather information from qualified industry parties for the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority (MBTA) to use in the development of technical specifications and other procurement documents for procurement of a new fleet of light rail vehicles for MBTA’s Green Line. These vehicles are designated the Green Line Type 10 Light Rail Vehicles and are conceptually described in the document GL10-
Goals of Green Line Transformation are to:
 Increase Green Line passenger capacity
 Increase the service reliability and safety of the Green Line
 Restore the entirety of the Green Line to a state of good repair
 Increase accessibility of the Green Line.  RFI responses due 04-17-19.
cards.name: RFI 54-19  - Green Line Type 10 Light Rail Vehicles Procurement.

The goal of this Request For Information ("RFI") is to identify commuter rail coach designs that are readily available and could be readily modified for use on the MBTA system.  In addition, this RFI seeks to determine what information is required by potential third party contractors to complete a bid on such a contract, as well as any other input potential Respondents would suggest for the development of the RFP..The MBTA is in the process of developing a technical specification for a fleet of up to 225 new bi-level coaches to replace the current single level fleet and accommodate increased ridership and planned system expansions.  

The Authority wishes to ensure that its specification requirements not only meet the Authority’s service and maintenance needs, but also allow for a competitive bid process that provides equal opportunity for many bidders.  To facilitate that process and maximize potential bidders, the MBTA has developed this RFI which seeks information from interested parties to assist the MBTA in development of specification requirements.   now bidding at: http://bc.mbta.com/business_center/bidding_solicitations/materials_management/invitation_for_bids/
cards.name: RFI 50-19 - 225 New Bi-Level Commuter Rail Coaches
